{
  "article_text": [
    "the standard model of elementary particles has had good agreement with experiments , in which masses of quarks and leptons are generated by the yukawa interactions with the higgs bosons .",
    "there , however , have been no experimental observations of the higgs boson , and moreover , there is a theoretical problem of the `` naturalness . ''",
    "therefore models without any elementary scalars have been considered@xcite as effective field theories to understand the origin of fermion masses : those are generated dynamically through the interaction @xmath1,\\ ] ] which is suppressed by inverse powers of a high energy scale @xmath2 , at energies much below it , that is , @xmath3 .",
    "it is called the nambu  jona - lasinio ( njl ) model@xcite and has been generalized to the one with the gauge interaction@xcite : @xmath4 .",
    "\\label{lqed}\\ ] ] although , in this model , nonperturbative approaches such as the schwinger  dyson equation with the ladder approximation@xcite or renormalization group@xcite give a nontrivial phase structure for chiral symmetry in a plane of gauge and four - fermi couplings , they suffer from gauge dependence . in the perturbative framework",
    "the inversion method@xcite does give a gauge - independent result@xcite , higher order calculations are tough tasks .    if we employ the perturbative effective action approach to the problem of chiral symmetry breaking(@xmath5sb ) , there is some room for improvement or simplification of the calculation from two viewpoints : ( i ) in view of the nonperturbative renormalization group approach@xcite , the critical behavior is successfully described in the local potential approximation : taking the lowest order of derivative expansion in the effective action .",
    "we , therefore , expect that it could also be good in the perturbative calculation .",
    "( ii ) after integrating with respect to matter ( fermionic ) fields the result must be gauge invariant , that is , be written as a functional of the field - strength tensor @xmath6 .",
    "therefore it is preferable to rewrite the functional integral of the gauge potential @xmath7 into that of @xmath6 .",
    "this could be a great help to the gauge - invariant calculation .",
    "indeed in the lattice gauge theory , a change of variables from gauge potentials to field strengths has been given@xcite , whose recipe , however , is specialized to the lattice . in the continuum theory ,",
    "the field - strength formulation has already been proposed@xcite .",
    "it is , however , based on the special choice of gauge  the coordinate gauge @xmath8 , which can not fix the gauge at the origin and moreover yields complicated fermionic currents with line integrals in the lagrangian . in this article",
    "we give a perturbative and gauge - independent method for calculating the dynamical fermion mass under the local potential approximation .",
    "inclusion of higher orders of the gauge coupling constant is simpler in this method .",
    "we use the functional integration not as a method simply reproducing perturbative diagrams systematically , but as `` integration '' with nice features : changing variables and introducing auxiliary variables can easily be made .",
    "we first construct a euclidean path integral expression in terms of the gauge field strength for the gauge sector with a conserved source @xmath9 : we start from the canonical formalism for quantization and find a suitable change of variables , which is the contents of sec .",
    "second , in sec .",
    "[ csb ] the fermionic partition function , minimally coupled to the gauge potential , in the local potential approximation is obtained by introducing auxiliary fields and by utilizing the fock - schwinger proper - time method@xcite . at last combining the above two partition functions and integrating with respect to the gauge field strength to obtain an effective potential of the dynamical fermion mass . the final sec .",
    "[ disc ] is devoted to a discussion .",
    "in this section we construct a euclidean path integral expression in 4-dimensional abelian gauge theory coupled to a conserved current @xmath9 , based on the canonical formalism@xcite , @xmath10 in order to show the gauge independence manifestly we fix the gauge in terms of an arbitrary real function @xmath11 satisfying@xcite @xmath12 the gauge fixing condition is@xcite @xmath13 which is satisfied by @xmath14 for an arbitrary @xmath15 . here",
    "we take a @xmath11 whose support is 3-dimensional and spacelike : @xmath16 with @xmath17 if it were not for this restriction , @xmath18 in eq .",
    "( [ physa ] ) is nonlocal in time , so that we can not follow the canonical procedure .",
    "( here and hereafter repeated indices @xmath19 , @xmath20 , @xmath21 , etc .",
    ", imply the summation over 1 to 3 . )",
    "the relation ( [ physa ] ) turns into @xmath22 where @xmath23 and the time argument has been omitted .",
    "hereafter we use an abbreviation like eq .",
    "( [ abb ] ) for simplicity ; all the functions of @xmath24 including @xmath25 and @xmath26 should be understood in the momentum space representation .",
    "the gauge - fixed variable @xmath27 must have two degrees of freedom out of three @xmath28 s , which can be singled out by considering the norm of the functional space @xmath29 where @xmath30 this matrix can be diagonalized as @xmath31 where @xmath32 s are given by @xmath33\\big/ \\sqrt{{\\boldsymbol{p}}^2({\\boldsymbol{p}}^2\\vert\\widetilde{\\boldsymbol f}({\\boldsymbol{p}})\\vert^2 - 1 ) } , \\label{ns}\\\\ n_{(3)}^k({\\boldsymbol{p}})&\\equiv&ip^k/\\vert{\\boldsymbol{p}}\\vert.\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and form an orthonormal base obeying @xmath34    in view of eqs .",
    "( [ norm ] ) and ( [ mdiag ] ) , genuine physical variables are given as @xmath35 with these variables the action is @xmath36^{2 } + j_{\\mu}(x)a^{\\mu}(x;\\phi)\\right\\}\\nonumber\\\\ & = & \\int\\!\\!d^{4}x\\,\\biggl\\{{1\\over2}\\sum_{\\alpha=1}^{2 } a^{(\\alpha)}(x){\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}}^{2}a^{(\\alpha)}(x ) + { 1\\over2}\\left[\\dot{a}^{(1)}(x)\\right]^{2 } \\nonumber\\\\ & & { } -{1\\over2}{\\dot{a}^{(2)}}(x)\\!{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}}^{2 } \\vert\\widetilde{\\boldsymbol f}(-i{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}})\\vert^{2 } { \\dot{a}^{(2)}}(x ) + { 1\\over2}\\left[{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla } } a^{0}(x;\\phi)\\right]^{2 } \\nonumber\\\\ & & { } -a^{0}(x;\\phi )     \\sqrt{{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}}^2({\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}}^2 \\vert\\widetilde{\\boldsymbol f}(-i{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla}})\\vert^2 + 1 ) } { \\dot{a}^{(2)}}(x )   \\label{b22}\\\\ & & { } + j_{0}(x)a^{0}(x;\\phi ) -{\\boldsymbol",
    "j}(x)\\!\\cdot\\!\\left[{\\boldsymbol a}(x;\\phi ) \\right]\\biggr\\ } , \\nonumber \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath37 $ ] in the last line is given by @xmath38a^{(2)}({\\boldsymbol{x } } ) .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the hamiltonian is written as @xmath39^{2 } + \\left[{\\boldsymbol{\\nabla } } a^{(\\alpha)}({\\boldsymbol{x}})\\right]^{2}\\right ) \\nonumber\\\\ & & { } +     "in this section , we consider fermionic system coupled minimally to the `` gauge potentials '' ( [ a4b ] ) and ( [ aib ] ) with the chirally invariant four - fermion interaction . the partition function is @xmath78=\\int\\!\\!{\\mathcal{d}}\\psi{\\mathcal{d}}{\\overline\\psi }      \\exp\\left[\\int\\!\\!d^{4}x_{_{e}}\\left\\{-{\\overline\\psi}\\gamma_{\\mu }      ( \\partial_{\\mu}-i{\\overline{a}}_{\\mu})\\psi      + { g^{2}\\over2}\\left[({\\overline\\psi}\\psi)^{2 }      + ( { \\overline\\psi}i\\gamma_{5}\\psi)^{2}\\right]\\right\\}\\right ] ,      \\label{za}\\ ] ] where the gauge coupling constant has been absorbed into @xmath79 .",
    "our scenario is as follows : introduce auxiliary fields to cancel the four - fermion interaction , and then integrate with respect to the fermionic fields and finally the gauge field strengths with the aid of the representation in the previous section .",
    "the result is a tree potential of the auxiliary field , with which we examine the dynamical mass generation of fermions .    after introducing auxiliary fields @xmath0 and @xmath80 , as usual , and integrating with respect to @xmath81 and @xmath82 , we have @xmath78=\\int\\!\\!{\\mathcal{d}}\\sigma{\\mathcal{d}}\\pi\\exp\\left [      -\\int\\!\\!d^{4}x_{_{e}}{\\sigma^{2}+\\pi^{2}\\over2g^{2 } }      + \\ln{\\mathrm{det}}\\left[\\gamma_{\\mu}(\\partial_{\\mu }      -i{\\overline{a}}_{\\mu})+\\sigma+i\\gamma_{5}\\pi\\right]\\right ] .      \\label{za1}\\ ] ] shifting as @xmath83 and @xmath84 and ignoring @xmath85 and @xmath86",
    ", we obtain the tree level potential of @xmath0(@xmath87 ) : @xmath78_{0}=      \\exp\\left[-\\int\\!\\!d^{4}x_{_{e}}{m^{2}\\over2g^{2 } }      + \\ln{\\mathrm{det}}\\left[\\gamma_{\\mu}(\\partial_{\\mu }      -i{\\overline{a}}_{\\mu})+m\\right]\\right ] .",
    "\\label{za2}\\ ] ] the exponent of eq .",
    "( [ za2 ] ) must be a functional of the field strength @xmath88 rather than @xmath89 as far as a regularization preserves the gauge invariance .",
    "we here employ the local potential approximation : we adopt the lowest order of derivative expansion , that is , discard any terms with differentials like @xmath90 , to obtain a polynomial of @xmath6 .",
    "this approximation seems to be valid , since we are interested only in a low energy phenomena , the chiral symmetry breaking , where contributions from large @xmath91 should be much less important .",
    "the functional form of the effective action under this approximation can be obtained nonperturbatively by the fock ",
    "schwinger s proper time method@xcite : @xmath78_{0}=      \\exp\\left[-\\int\\!\\!d^{^{d}}\\!\\!x_{_{e}}\\left\\{{m^{2}\\over2g^{2 } }      + { 1\\over2(2\\pi)^{{d\\over2}}}\\lim_{s\\rightarrow0 }      \\int_{0}^{\\infty}\\!\\!d\\tau\\ ,      \\tau^{s-{d\\over2}-1}{\\mathrm{e}}^{-\\tau m^{2}}g(\\tau f )      \\right\\}\\right ] ,      \\label{za3}\\ ] ] where @xmath92 to evaluate the @xmath93-integration in eq .",
    "( [ za3 ] ) , we expand @xmath94 as @xmath95      \\nonumber\\\\      & & + { 1\\over945}\\left[2(f_{+}^{2}+f_{-}^{2})^{3 }      -13f_{+}^{2}f_{-}^{2}(f_{+}^{2}+f_{-}^{2})\\right]+o(f^{8 } ) .      \\label{ge}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] we need some regularization : in order to reproduce the njl result in the limit @xmath96 , we need an ultraviolet cutoff @xmath2 which is introduced by a modification of the range of the @xmath93-integration to @xmath97",
    ". however , this proper - time cutoff breaks the gauge invariance in the same way as the momentum - space cutoff , contrary to the dimensional regularization ( @xmath98 ) . to overcome this difficulty , we employ both regularizations at the same time .",
    "we use the cutoff for the zeroth order in the gauge coupling , since it has nothing to do with gauge fields . while , for higher orders , the dimensional regularization is used in the effective action . compare two expressions of the zeroth order effective action , eq .",
    "( [ vo ] ) by the proper - time cutoff after expanding in terms of @xmath99 , @xmath100,\\ ] ] and one by the dimensional regularization , @xmath101.\\ ] ] ] .",
    "the result is @xmath102_{0 } & = &       \\exp\\biggl[-\\int\\!\\!d^{4}x_{_{e}}\\biggl\\{{m^{2}\\over2g^{2 } }       + { 1\\over8\\pi^{2}}\\biggl[{\\lambda^{4}\\over2 }       \\bigl(1-{m^{2}\\over\\lambda^{2}}\\bigr )       { \\mathrm{e}}^{-{m^{2}\\over\\lambda^{2 } } }       + { m^{4}\\over2}e_{1}({m^{2}/\\lambda^{2 } } )      \\nonumber   \\\\       &   & { } + { 1\\over3}\\bigl({1\\over{\\overline{\\epsilon } } }      + \\ln{\\mu^{2}\\over m^{2}}\\bigr )      { f_{\\mu\\nu}f_{\\mu\\nu}\\over2 }      -{1\\over45m^{4}}\\biggl [      \\left({f_{\\mu\\nu}f_{\\mu\\nu}\\over2}\\right)^{2 }      -7\\bigl({f_{\\mu\\nu}{\\widetilde{f}}_{\\mu\\nu}\\over4}\\bigr)^{2 }      \\biggr]\\hspace*{20pt }      \\nonumber   \\\\       &   &       { } + { 2\\over315m^{8}}\\biggl [      2\\left({f_{\\mu\\nu}f_{\\mu\\nu}\\over2}\\right)^{3 }      -13\\bigl({f_{\\mu\\nu}{\\widetilde{f}}_{\\mu\\nu}\\over4}\\bigr)^{2 }      { f_{\\mu\\nu}f_{\\mu\\nu}\\over2}\\biggr]+o(f^{8 } )      \\biggr]\\biggr\\}\\biggr ] ,      \\label{za4}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath103 and @xmath104 is a renormalization scale .",

    "let us first consider the lowest correction , up to the @xmath141 term .",
    "the @xmath142-integration is analytically performed to give @xmath138=\\prod_{\\{\\mbox{site}\\}}2^{15/2}\\pi^{3}\\exp[-v(x)]\\ ] ] where @xmath143\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] with @xmath144 and @xmath145 .",
    "the argument of the logarithm becomes negative at the landau pole @xmath146 $ ] , but we do not care such a heavy fermion and thus assume that the argument is always positive .",
    "the stationary point @xmath147 defined by @xmath148 should satisfy the stability condition @xmath149 for which @xmath150 is a sufficient condition . to solve eq .",

    "( [ sol3 ] ) @xmath176 @xmath177 is highly suppressed even at this scale ( @xmath175 tev ) .",
    "now we include the higher order terms .",
    "we evaluate the @xmath142-integration with the wkb approximation ; @xmath178      \\simeq(2\\pi)^{{1\\over2}}\\exp\\left[-\\left\\{v_{_{f}}(r_{0}(x);x )      + { 1\\over2}\\ln\\left[v''_{_{f}}(r_{0}(x);x)\\right]\\right\\}\\right],\\ ] ] where the superscript @xmath179 denotes the @xmath142-differentiation and @xmath180 is a solution of the stationary point equation @xmath181=0 ,      \\label{stpeq}\\ ] ] which is the cubic equation of @xmath182 .",
    "there exists only one real - positive solution for @xmath182 , @xmath183^{{1\\over3 } }      -\\left[p(x)-q(x)\\right]^{{1\\over3}}\\right\\},\\ ] ] where @xmath184 since @xmath185 from ( [ cx ] ) and @xmath186 turns out to be @xmath187 positivity of @xmath188 @xmath189>0\\ ] ] is also guaranteed , since the sufficient condition @xmath190 is fulfilled .",
    "[ this leads to a similar condition as eq .",
    "( [ condition ] ) . ]",
    "the final form of the partition function is @xmath138=\\prod_{\\{\\mbox{site}\\}}2^{10}\\pi^{3}\\exp[-v(x)],\\ ] ] with @xmath191      \\nonumber   \\\\       & = & v_{0}(x)+{1\\over3}+{2\\over3}a(x)r_{0}(x)^{2 }       -{1\\over3}b(x)r_{0}(x)^{4 }      \\label{vfinal }   \\\\       &   & { } + { 1\\over2}\\ln       \\left[{12c(x)\\{3 - 2a(x)r_{0}(x)^{2}+2b(x)r_{0}(x)^{4}\\ }       \\over1-a(x)r_{0}(x)^{2}+2br_{0}(x)^{4}}\\right ] ,      \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where eq .",
    "( [ stpeq ] ) has been used .",
    "differentiating this with respect to @xmath192 gives us the gap equation , whose numerical solution is shown in fig .",
    "[ fig2 ] . in comparison with fig .",
    "[ fig1 ] , there is a large deviation in the region where both @xmath130 and @xmath144 are small , and the mass is increased by higher order corrections .    for sufficiently small @xmath192 , @xmath193 or @xmath194 , eq .",
    "( [ vfinal ] ) can be expanded : @xmath195 yielding the gap equation @xmath196 the stability condition @xmath197 is fulfilled for @xmath198 and @xmath199 .",
    "therefore an @xmath200-independent solution exists : @xmath201 for @xmath192 obeying @xmath194 and eq .",
    "( [ genecon ] ) . in this case",
    "@xmath177 is also highly suppressed : @xmath202 for @xmath174 , that is , @xmath175 tev .",
    "we give a gauge invariant recipe for calculating the effective action in qed with the four - fermion interaction .",
    "we use perturbation and the local potential approximation to study the dynamical fermion mass . in order to include the higher orders of the gauge coupling constant we just expand the completely known function ( [ g ] ) into a polynomial of @xmath203 $ ] and @xmath204 $ ] and integrate with respect to the proper - time @xmath93 .",
    "the last task is to evaluate the triple integral of @xmath205 , @xmath206 , and @xmath207 . in this article",
    "we employ the wkb approximation for it , which , however , can not be performed in an elementary manner when higher orders are included further .",
    "meanwhile the ordinary perturbative treatment , considering the gaussian part the kernel and expanding the exponential of higher parts than the third order , can always be ensured .",
    "as for the local potential approximation its efficacy is still open . in order to go beyond the local potential approximation , we must perform the functional integration of @xmath116 , @xmath117 , and @xmath118 , instead of the ordinary integration like ( [ zt1 ] ) .",
    "for example , an @xmath208 quantity after integrating with respect to the gauge fields would be @xmath209 where @xmath210 so that @xmath211 the local potential approximation is to expand @xmath212 in terms of @xmath213 and keep the lowest . since the change of variables , eq .",
    "( [ cvff ] ) , gives @xmath214 , the leading correction to the local potential approximation is @xmath215 therefore we must calculate the effective potential with the help of the feynman graphs using the propagators of @xmath116 , @xmath117 , and @xmath118 .",
    "our result indicates that chiral symmetry is always broken for any @xmath168 and @xmath171 as is seen from figs .",
    "[ fig1 ] and [ fig2 ] .",
    "this seems to be different from previous results@xcite which claim that there is a nonzero @xmath162 if @xmath216 .",
    "it is , however , too early to conclude , since our present work is restricted only to the tree level of auxiliary fields and thus no higher orders of @xmath171 are included . as is seen from the figs .",
    "[ fig1 ] and [ fig2 ] , the small negative correction , linear in @xmath171 , to dynamical mass could easily swallow the broken region .",
    "from a recent study@xcite , the one - loop inclusion of the auxiliary fields is promising .",
    "thus a further study must be necessary for a definite conclusion .",
    "in qed the functional integral in terms of the field strength can be constructed , since the configuration space of the gauge potential as well as the field strength is trivial enough for the gauge to be completely fixed .",
    "it is challenging to generalize eq .",
    "( [ zf ] ) to qcd where an obstacle for gauge fixing , the gribov ambiguity@xcite , exists .",
    "in order to examine the dynamics of chiral symmetry breaking and color confinement in qcd , this must be done and the choice of convenient variables describing the low energy phenomena@xcite must be necessary .",
    "these directions of study are in progress .",
    "the author thanks t.  kashiwa and k.  harada for discussions and encouragements and also thanks d.  mcmullan for discussions .    99 s.  weinberg , phys .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the chiral symmetry breaking in the 4-dimensional qed with the chirally invariant four - fermion interaction is discussed by using a novel path integral expression in terms of the field - strength tensor . in the local potential approximation </S>",
    "<S> , we find that the chiral symmetry is spontaneously broken for any nonzero gauge and four - fermion couplings on the tree level of an auxiliary field @xmath0 . </S>",
    "<S> the present approach allows us to easily include higher orders of the gauge coupling so that the effective potential up to the sixth order is obtained . </S>"
  ]
}
